results.title: Confirmatory factor analysis of the ADNI Neuropsychological Battery.
results.authors: Park LQ, Gross AL, McLaren DG, Pa J, Johnson JK, Mitchell M, Manly JJ; Alzheimer’s Disease Neuroimaging Initiative.
results.snippet: Confirmatory factor analysis (CFA) of 23 variables from 10 neuropsychological tests resulted in five factors (memory, language, visuospatial functioning, attention, and executive function/processing speed) that were invariant across levels of cognitive impairment. T …

results.title: Neuropsychological test performance and cognitive reserve in healthy aging and the Alzheimer's disease spectrum: a theoretically driven factor analysis.
results.authors: Mitchell MB, Shaughnessy LW, Shirk SD, Yang FM, Atri A.
results.snippet: Statistical models of cognitive performance that include cognitive reserve can improve sensitivity to change and clinical efficacy. We used confirmatory factor analysis to test a four-factor model composed of memory/language, processing speed/executive function, att …

results.title: Neuropsychological assessment of driving safety risk in older adults with and without neurologic disease.
results.authors: Anderson SW, Aksan N, Dawson JD, Uc EY, Johnson AM, Rizzo M.
results.snippet: Decline in cognitive abilities can be an important contributor to the driving problems encountered by older adults, and neuropsychological assessment may provide a practical approach to evaluating this aspect of driving safety risk. ...Performances on all neuropsychologica …

results.title: Psychometric evaluation of the Swedish version of the Person-Centered Care Assessment Tool (P-CAT).
results.authors: Sjögren K, Lindkvist M, Sandman PO, Zingmark K, Edvardsson D.
results.snippet: METHODS: A cross-sectional sample of 1465 staff from 195 residential care units for older people in Sweden participated in the study. Validity, reliability, and discrimination ability of the scale were evaluated. RESULTS: Confirmatory factor analysis, paralle …

results.title: Self-reported depressive syndromes in mild cognitive impairment and mild Alzheimer's disease.

results.snippet: METHODS: Participants were 228 older adults (mean age = 74, SD = 7.9) diagnosed with mild cognitive impairment (MCI; n = 137) or early Alzheimer's disease (n = 85), who completed the BDI-II as part of an outpatient neuropsychological evaluation. Exploratory principa …

results.title: Evaluation of a Japanese version of the Mini-Mental State Examination in elderly persons.

results.snippet: AIM: This study aimed to examine the validity and item-response characteristics of the Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE), which is used for assessing cognitive function, in Japanese older adults. METHODS: Factor analysis and item response analysis were car …

results.title: The Fear of Alzheimer's Disease Scale: a new measure designed to assess anticipatory dementia in older adults.
results.authors: French SL, Floyd M, Wilkins S, Osato S.

results.snippet: METHODS: The current study utilized 101 older adults ages 65 to 91 to develop and validate an important new scale, the Fear of Alzheimer's Disease Scale (FADS). ...CONCLUSION: The FADS is a reliable and valid instrument and is the first of its kind available to dire …

results.title: The Telephone Interview for Cognitive Status (Modified): relation with a comprehensive neuropsychological assessment.
results.authors: van den Berg E, Ruis C, Biessels GJ, Kappelle LJ, van Zandvoort MJ.
results.snippet: The modified Telephone Interview for Cognitive Status (TICS-m) is a widely used screening instrument for (Alzheimer's) dementia. Psychometric evaluation of the TICS-m is limited. This study examined the relation between the TICS-m and a comprehensive neuropsychological ass …

results.title: Subjective cognitive complaints of older adults at the population level: an item response theory analysis.

results.title: Association of social engagement with brain volumes assessed by structural MRI.
